SCENE.TITLE: SCENE I. Rome. A street.
SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter FLAVIUS, MARULLUS, and certain Commoners

SPEECH.SPEAKER: FLAVIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Hence! home, you idle creatures get you home:
Is this a holiday? what! know you not,
Being mechanical, you ought not walk
Upon a labouring day without the sign
Of your profession? Speak, what trade art thou?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Commoner
SPEECH.LINE: Why, sir, a carpenter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MARULLUS
SPEECH.LINE: Where is thy leather apron and thy rule?
What dost thou with thy best apparel on?
You, sir, what trade are you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Second Commoner
SPEECH.LINE: Truly, sir, in respect of a fine workman, I am but,
as you would say, a cobbler.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MARULLUS
SPEECH.LINE: But what trade art thou? answer me directly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Second Commoner
SPEECH.LINE: A trade, sir, that, I hope, I may use with a safe
conscience; which is, indeed, sir, a mender of bad soles.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MARULLUS
SPEECH.LINE: What trade, thou knave? thou naughty knave, what trade?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Second Commoner
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, I beseech you, sir, be not out with me: yet,
if you be out, sir, I can mend you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MARULLUS
SPEECH.LINE: What meanest thou by that? mend me, thou saucy fellow!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Second Commoner
SPEECH.LINE: Why, sir, cobble you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: FLAVIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Thou art a cobbler, art thou?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Second Commoner
SPEECH.LINE: Truly, sir, all that I live by is with the awl: I
meddle with no tradesman's matters, nor women's
matters, but with awl. I am, indeed, sir, a surgeon
to old shoes; when they are in great danger, I
recover them. As proper men as ever trod upon
neat's leather have gone upon my handiwork.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: FLAVIUS
SPEECH.LINE: But wherefore art not in thy shop today?
Why dost thou lead these men about the streets?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Second Commoner
SPEECH.LINE: Truly, sir, to wear out their shoes, to get myself
into more work. But, indeed, sir, we make holiday,
to see Caesar and to rejoice in his triumph.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MARULLUS
SPEECH.LINE: Wherefore rejoice? What conquest brings he home?
What tributaries follow him to Rome,
To grace in captive bonds his chariot-wheels?
You blocks, you stones, you worse than senseless things!
O you hard hearts, you cruel men of Rome,
Knew you not Pompey? Many a time and oft
Have you climb'd up to walls and battlements,
To towers and windows, yea, to chimney-tops,
Your infants in your arms, and there have sat
The livelong day, with patient expectation,
To see great Pompey pass the streets of Rome:
And when you saw his chariot but appear,
Have you not made an universal shout,
That Tiber trembled underneath her banks,
To hear the replication of your sounds
Made in her concave shores?
And do you now put on your best attire?
And do you now cull out a holiday?
And do you now strew flowers in his way
That comes in triumph over Pompey's blood? Be gone!
Run to your houses, fall upon your knees,
Pray to the gods to intermit the plague
That needs must light on this ingratitude.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: FLAVIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Go, go, good countrymen, and, for this fault,
Assemble all the poor men of your sort;
Draw them to Tiber banks, and weep your tears
Into the channel, till the lowest stream
Do kiss the most exalted shores of all.
See whether their basest metal be not moved;
They vanish tongue-tied in their guiltiness.
Go you down that way towards the Capitol;
This way will I disrobe the images,
If you do find them deck'd with ceremonies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MARULLUS
SPEECH.LINE: May we do so?
You know it is the feast of Lupercal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: FLAVIUS
SPEECH.LINE: It is no matter; let no images
Be hung with Caesar's trophies. I'll about,
And drive away the vulgar from the streets:
So do you too, where you perceive them thick.
These growing feathers pluck'd from Caesar's wing
Will make him fly an ordinary pitch,
Who else would soar above the view of men
And keep us all in servile fearfulness.

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE II. A public place.
SCENE.STAGEDIR: Flourish. Enter CAESAR; ANTONY, for the course; CALPURNIA, PORTIA, DECIUS BRUTUS, CICERO, BRUTUS, CASSIUS, and CASCA; a great crowd following, among them a Soothsayer

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CAESAR
SPEECH.LINE: Calpurnia!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASCA
SPEECH.LINE: Peace, ho! Caesar speaks.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CAESAR
SPEECH.LINE: Calpurnia!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CALPURNIA
SPEECH.LINE: Here, my lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CAESAR
SPEECH.LINE: Stand you directly in Antonius' way,
When he doth run his course. Antonius!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTONY
SPEECH.LINE: Caesar, my lord?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CAESAR
SPEECH.LINE: Forget not, in your speed, Antonius,
To touch Calpurnia; for our elders say,
The barren, touched in this holy chase,
Shake off their sterile curse.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTONY
SPEECH.LINE: I shall remember:
When Caesar says 'do this,' it is perform'd.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CAESAR
SPEECH.LINE: Set on; and leave no ceremony out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Soothsayer
SPEECH.LINE: Caesar!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CAESAR
SPEECH.LINE: Ha! who calls?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASCA
SPEECH.LINE: Bid every noise be still: peace yet again!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CAESAR
SPEECH.LINE: Who is it in the press that calls on me?
I hear a tongue, shriller than all the music,
Cry 'Caesar!' Speak; Caesar is turn'd to hear.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Soothsayer
SPEECH.LINE: Beware the ides of March.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CAESAR
SPEECH.LINE: What man is that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: A soothsayer bids you beware the ides of March.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CAESAR
SPEECH.LINE: Set him before me; let me see his face.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASSIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Fellow, come from the throng; look upon Caesar.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CAESAR
SPEECH.LINE: What say'st thou to me now? speak once again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Soothsayer
SPEECH.LINE: Beware the ides of March.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CAESAR
SPEECH.LINE: He is a dreamer; let us leave him: pass.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Sennet. Exeunt all except BRUTUS and CASSIUS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASSIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Will you go see the order of the course?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Not I.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASSIUS
SPEECH.LINE: I pray you, do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: I am not gamesome: I do lack some part
Of that quick spirit that is in Antony.
Let me not hinder, Cassius, your desires;
I'll leave you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASSIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Brutus, I do observe you now of late:
I have not from your eyes that gentleness
And show of love as I was wont to have:
You bear too stubborn and too strange a hand
Over your friend that loves you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Cassius,
Be not deceived: if I have veil'd my look,
I turn the trouble of my countenance
Merely upon myself. Vexed I am
Of late with passions of some difference,
Conceptions only proper to myself,
Which give some soil perhaps to my behaviors;
But let not therefore my good friends be grieved--
Among which number, Cassius, be you one--
Nor construe any further my neglect,
Than that poor Brutus, with himself at war,
Forgets the shows of love to other men.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASSIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Then, Brutus, I have much mistook your passion;
By means whereof this breast of mine hath buried
Thoughts of great value, worthy cogitations.
Tell me, good Brutus, can you see your face?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: No, Cassius; for the eye sees not itself,
But by reflection, by some other things.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASSIUS
SPEECH.LINE: 'Tis just:
And it is very much lamented, Brutus,
That you have no such mirrors as will turn
Your hidden worthiness into your eye,
That you might see your shadow. I have heard,
Where many of the best respect in Rome,
Except immortal Caesar, speaking of Brutus
And groaning underneath this age's yoke,
Have wish'd that noble Brutus had his eyes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Into what dangers would you lead me, Cassius,
That you would have me seek into myself
For that which is not in me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASSIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Therefore, good Brutus, be prepared to hear:
And since you know you cannot see yourself
So well as by reflection, I, your glass,
Will modestly discover to yourself
That of yourself which you yet know not of.
And be not jealous on me, gentle Brutus:
Were I a common laugher, or did use
To stale with ordinary oaths my love
To every new protester; if you know
That I do fawn on men and hug them hard
And after scandal them, or if you know
That I profess myself in banqueting
To all the rout, then hold me dangerous.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: What means this shouting? I do fear, the people
Choose Caesar for their king.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASSIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, do you fear it?
Then must I think you would not have it so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: I would not, Cassius; yet I love him well.
But wherefore do you hold me here so long?
What is it that you would impart to me?
If it be aught toward the general good,
Set honour in one eye and death i' the other,
And I will look on both indifferently,
For let the gods so speed me as I love
The name of honour more than I fear death.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASSIUS
SPEECH.LINE: I know that virtue to be in you, Brutus,
As well as I do know your outward favour.
Well, honour is the subject of my story.
I cannot tell what you and other men
Think of this life; but, for my single self,
I had as lief not be as live to be
In awe of such a thing as I myself.
I was born free as Caesar; so were you:
We both have fed as well, and we can both
Endure the winter's cold as well as he:
For once, upon a raw and gusty day,
The troubled Tiber chafing with her shores,
Caesar said to me 'Darest thou, Cassius, now
Leap in with me into this angry flood,
And swim to yonder point?' Upon the word,
Accoutred as I was, I plunged in
And bade him follow; so indeed he did.
The torrent roar'd, and we did buffet it
With lusty sinews, throwing it aside
And stemming it with hearts of controversy;
But ere we could arrive the point proposed,
Caesar cried 'Help me, Cassius, or I sink!'
I, as Aeneas, our great ancestor,
Did from the flames of Troy upon his shoulder
The old Anchises bear, so from the waves of Tiber
Did I the tired Caesar. And this man
Is now become a god, and Cassius is
A wretched creature and must bend his body,
If Caesar carelessly but nod on him.
He had a fever when he was in Spain,
And when the fit was on him, I did mark
How he did shake: 'tis true, this god did shake;
His coward lips did from their colour fly,
And that same eye whose bend doth awe the world
Did lose his lustre: I did hear him groan:
Ay, and that tongue of his that bade the Romans
Mark him and write his speeches in their books,
Alas, it cried 'Give me some drink, Titinius,'
As a sick girl. Ye gods, it doth amaze me
A man of such a feeble temper should
So get the start of the majestic world
And bear the palm alone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Another general shout!
I do believe that these applauses are
For some new honours that are heap'd on Caesar.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASSIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Why, man, he doth bestride the narrow world
Like a Colossus, and we petty men
Walk under his huge legs and peep about
To find ourselves dishonourable graves.
Men at some time are masters of their fates:
The fault, dear Brutus, is not in our stars,
But in ourselves, that we are underlings.
Brutus and Caesar: what should be in that 'Caesar'?
Why should that name be sounded more than yours?
Write them together, yours is as fair a name;
Sound them, it doth become the mouth as well;
Weigh them, it is as heavy; conjure with 'em,
Brutus will start a spirit as soon as Caesar.
Now, in the names of all the gods at once,
Upon what meat doth this our Caesar feed,
That he is grown so great? Age, thou art shamed!
Rome, thou hast lost the breed of noble bloods!
When went there by an age, since the great flood,
But it was famed with more than with one man?
When could they say till now, that talk'd of Rome,
That her wide walls encompass'd but one man?
Now is it Rome indeed and room enough,
When there is in it but one only man.
O, you and I have heard our fathers say,
There was a Brutus once that would have brook'd
The eternal devil to keep his state in Rome
As easily as a king.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: That you do love me, I am nothing jealous;
What you would work me to, I have some aim:
How I have thought of this and of these times,
I shall recount hereafter; for this present,
I would not, so with love I might entreat you,
Be any further moved. What you have said
I will consider; what you have to say
I will with patience hear, and find a time
Both meet to hear and answer such high things.
Till then, my noble friend, chew upon this:
Brutus had rather be a villager
Than to repute himself a son of Rome
Under these hard conditions as this time
Is like to lay upon us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASSIUS
SPEECH.LINE: I am glad that my weak words
Have struck but thus much show of fire from Brutus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: The games are done and Caesar is returning.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASSIUS
SPEECH.LINE: As they pass by, pluck Casca by the sleeve;
And he will, after his sour fashion, tell you
What hath proceeded worthy note to-day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: I will do so. But, look you, Cassius,
The angry spot doth glow on Caesar's brow,
And all the rest look like a chidden train:
Calpurnia's cheek is pale; and Cicero
Looks with such ferret and such fiery eyes
As we have seen him in the Capitol,
Being cross'd in conference by some senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASSIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Casca will tell us what the matter is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CAESAR
SPEECH.LINE: Antonius!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTONY
SPEECH.LINE: Caesar?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CAESAR
SPEECH.LINE: Let me have men about me that are fat;
Sleek-headed men and such as sleep o' nights:
Yond Cassius has a lean and hungry look;
He thinks too much: such men are dangerous.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTONY
SPEECH.LINE: Fear him not, Caesar; he's not dangerous;
He is a noble Roman and well given.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CAESAR
SPEECH.LINE: Would he were fatter! But I fear him not:
Yet if my name were liable to fear,
I do not know the man I should avoid
So soon as that spare Cassius. He reads much;
He is a great observer and he looks
Quite through the deeds of men: he loves no plays,
As thou dost, Antony; he hears no music;
Seldom he smiles, and smiles in such a sort
As if he mock'd himself and scorn'd his spirit
That could be moved to smile at any thing.
Such men as he be never at heart's ease
Whiles they behold a greater than themselves,
And therefore are they very dangerous.
I rather tell thee what is to be fear'd
Than what I fear; for always I am Caesar.
Come on my right hand, for this ear is deaf,
And tell me truly what thou think'st of him.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Sennet. Exeunt CAESAR and all his Train, but CASCA

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASCA
SPEECH.LINE: You pull'd me by the cloak; would you speak with me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, Casca; tell us what hath chanced to-day,
That Caesar looks so sad.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASCA
SPEECH.LINE: Why, you were with him, were you not?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: I should not then ask Casca what had chanced.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASCA
SPEECH.LINE: Why, there was a crown offered him: and being
offered him, he put it by with the back of his hand,
thus; and then the people fell a-shouting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: What was the second noise for?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASCA
SPEECH.LINE: Why, for that too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASSIUS
SPEECH.LINE: They shouted thrice: what was the last cry for?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASCA
SPEECH.LINE: Why, for that too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Was the crown offered him thrice?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASCA
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, marry, was't, and he put it by thrice, every
time gentler than other, and at every putting-by
mine honest neighbours shouted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASSIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Who offered him the crown?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASCA
SPEECH.LINE: Why, Antony.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Tell us the manner of it, gentle Casca.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASCA
SPEECH.LINE: I can as well be hanged as tell the manner of it:
it was mere foolery; I did not mark it. I saw Mark
Antony offer him a crown;--yet 'twas not a crown
neither, 'twas one of these coronets;--and, as I told
you, he put it by once: but, for all that, to my
thinking, he would fain have had it. Then he
offered it to him again; then he put it by again:
but, to my thinking, he was very loath to lay his
fingers off it. And then he offered it the third
time; he put it the third time by: and still as he
refused it, the rabblement hooted and clapped their
chapped hands and threw up their sweaty night-caps
and uttered such a deal of stinking breath because
Caesar refused the crown that it had almost choked
Caesar; for he swounded and fell down at it: and
for mine own part, I durst not laugh, for fear of
opening my lips and receiving the bad air.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASSIUS
SPEECH.LINE: But, soft, I pray you: what, did Caesar swound?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASCA
SPEECH.LINE: He fell down in the market-place, and foamed at
mouth, and was speechless.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: 'Tis very like: he hath the failing sickness.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASSIUS
SPEECH.LINE: No, Caesar hath it not; but you and I,
And honest Casca, we have the falling sickness.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASCA
SPEECH.LINE: I know not what you mean by that; but, I am sure,
Caesar fell down. If the tag-rag people did not
clap him and hiss him, according as he pleased and
displeased them, as they use to do the players in
the theatre, I am no true man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: What said he when he came unto himself?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASCA
SPEECH.LINE: Marry, before he fell down, when he perceived the
common herd was glad he refused the crown, he
plucked me ope his doublet and offered them his
throat to cut. An I had been a man of any
occupation, if I would not have taken him at a word,
I would I might go to hell among the rogues. And so
he fell. When he came to himself again, he said,
If he had done or said any thing amiss, he desired
their worships to think it was his infirmity. Three
or four wenches, where I stood, cried 'Alas, good
soul!' and forgave him with all their hearts: but
there's no heed to be taken of them; if Caesar had
stabbed their mothers, they would have done no less.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: And after that, he came, thus sad, away?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASCA
SPEECH.LINE: Ay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASSIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Did Cicero say any thing?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASCA
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, he spoke Greek.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASSIUS
SPEECH.LINE: To what effect?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASCA
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, an I tell you that, Ill ne'er look you i' the
face again: but those that understood him smiled at
one another and shook their heads; but, for mine own
part, it was Greek to me. I could tell you more
news too: Marullus and Flavius, for pulling scarfs
off Caesar's images, are put to silence. Fare you
well. There was more foolery yet, if I could
remember it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASSIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Will you sup with me to-night, Casca?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASCA
SPEECH.LINE: No, I am promised forth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASSIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Will you dine with me to-morrow?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASCA
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, if I be alive and your mind hold and your dinner
worth the eating.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASSIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Good: I will expect you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASCA
SPEECH.LINE: Do so. Farewell, both.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: What a blunt fellow is this grown to be!
He was quick mettle when he went to school.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASSIUS
SPEECH.LINE: So is he now in execution
Of any bold or noble enterprise,
However he puts on this tardy form.
This rudeness is a sauce to his good wit,
Which gives men stomach to digest his words
With better appetite.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: And so it is. For this time I will leave you:
To-morrow, if you please to speak with me,
I will come home to you; or, if you will,
Come home to me, and I will wait for you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASSIUS
SPEECH.LINE: I will do so: till then, think of the world.
Well, Brutus, thou art noble; yet, I see,
Thy honourable metal may be wrought
From that it is disposed: therefore it is meet
That noble minds keep ever with their likes;
For who so firm that cannot be seduced?
Caesar doth bear me hard; but he loves Brutus:
If I were Brutus now and he were Cassius,
He should not humour me. I will this night,
In several hands, in at his windows throw,
As if they came from several citizens,
Writings all tending to the great opinion
That Rome holds of his name; wherein obscurely
Caesar's ambition shall be glanced at:
And after this let Caesar seat him sure;
For we will shake him, or worse days endure.

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE III. The same. A street.
SCENE.STAGEDIR: Thunder and lightning. Enter from opposite sides, CASCA, with his sword drawn, and CICERO

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CICERO
SPEECH.LINE: Good even, Casca: brought you Caesar home?
Why are you breathless? and why stare you so?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASCA
SPEECH.LINE: Are not you moved, when all the sway of earth
Shakes like a thing unfirm? O Cicero,
I have seen tempests, when the scolding winds
Have rived the knotty oaks, and I have seen
The ambitious ocean swell and rage and foam,
To be exalted with the threatening clouds:
But never till to-night, never till now,
Did I go through a tempest dropping fire.
Either there is a civil strife in heaven,
Or else the world, too saucy with the gods,
Incenses them to send destruction.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CICERO
SPEECH.LINE: Why, saw you any thing more wonderful?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASCA
SPEECH.LINE: A common slave--you know him well by sight--
Held up his left hand, which did flame and burn
Like twenty torches join'd, and yet his hand,
Not sensible of fire, remain'd unscorch'd.
Besides--I ha' not since put up my sword--
Against the Capitol I met a lion,
Who glared upon me, and went surly by,
Without annoying me: and there were drawn
Upon a heap a hundred ghastly women,
Transformed with their fear; who swore they saw
Men all in fire walk up and down the streets.
And yesterday the bird of night did sit
Even at noon-day upon the market-place,
Hooting and shrieking. When these prodigies
Do so conjointly meet, let not men say
'These are their reasons; they are natural;'
For, I believe, they are portentous things
Unto the climate that they point upon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CICERO
SPEECH.LINE: Indeed, it is a strange-disposed time:
But men may construe things after their fashion,
Clean from the purpose of the things themselves.
Come Caesar to the Capitol to-morrow?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASCA
SPEECH.LINE: He doth; for he did bid Antonius
Send word to you he would be there to-morrow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CICERO
SPEECH.LINE: Good night then, Casca: this disturbed sky
Is not to walk in.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASCA
SPEECH.LINE: Farewell, Cicero.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASSIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Who's there?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASCA
SPEECH.LINE: A Roman.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASSIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Casca, by your voice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASCA
SPEECH.LINE: Your ear is good. Cassius, what night is this!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASSIUS
SPEECH.LINE: A very pleasing night to honest men.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASCA
SPEECH.LINE: Who ever knew the heavens menace so?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASSIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Those that have known the earth so full of faults.
For my part, I have walk'd about the streets,
Submitting me unto the perilous night,
And, thus unbraced, Casca, as you see,
Have bared my bosom to the thunder-stone;
And when the cross blue lightning seem'd to open
The breast of heaven, I did present myself
Even in the aim and very flash of it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASCA
SPEECH.LINE: But wherefore did you so much tempt the heavens?
It is the part of men to fear and tremble,
When the most mighty gods by tokens send
Such dreadful heralds to astonish us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASSIUS
SPEECH.LINE: You are dull, Casca, and those sparks of life
That should be in a Roman you do want,
Or else you use not. You look pale and gaze
And put on fear and cast yourself in wonder,
To see the strange impatience of the heavens:
But if you would consider the true cause
Why all these fires, why all these gliding ghosts,
Why birds and beasts from quality and kind,
Why old men fool and children calculate,
Why all these things change from their ordinance
Their natures and preformed faculties
To monstrous quality,--why, you shall find
That heaven hath infused them with these spirits,
To make them instruments of fear and warning
Unto some monstrous state.
Now could I, Casca, name to thee a man
Most like this dreadful night,
That thunders, lightens, opens graves, and roars
As doth the lion in the Capitol,
A man no mightier than thyself or me
In personal action, yet prodigious grown
And fearful, as these strange eruptions are.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASCA
SPEECH.LINE: 'Tis Caesar that you mean; is it not, Cassius?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASSIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Let it be who it is: for Romans now
Have thews and limbs like to their ancestors;
But, woe the while! our fathers' minds are dead,
And we are govern'd with our mothers' spirits;
Our yoke and sufferance show us womanish.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASCA
SPEECH.LINE: Indeed, they say the senators tomorrow
Mean to establish Caesar as a king;
And he shall wear his crown by sea and land,
In every place, save here in Italy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASSIUS
SPEECH.LINE: I know where I will wear this dagger then;
Cassius from bondage will deliver Cassius:
Therein, ye gods, you make the weak most strong;
Therein, ye gods, you tyrants do defeat:
Nor stony tower, nor walls of beaten brass,
Nor airless dungeon, nor strong links of iron,
Can be retentive to the strength of spirit;
But life, being weary of these worldly bars,
Never lacks power to dismiss itself.
If I know this, know all the world besides,
That part of tyranny that I do bear
I can shake off at pleasure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASCA
SPEECH.LINE: So can I:
So every bondman in his own hand bears
The power to cancel his captivity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASSIUS
SPEECH.LINE: And why should Caesar be a tyrant then?
Poor man! I know he would not be a wolf,
But that he sees the Romans are but sheep:
He were no lion, were not Romans hinds.
Those that with haste will make a mighty fire
Begin it with weak straws: what trash is Rome,
What rubbish and what offal, when it serves
For the base matter to illuminate
So vile a thing as Caesar! But, O grief,
Where hast thou led me? I perhaps speak this
Before a willing bondman; then I know
My answer must be made. But I am arm'd,
And dangers are to me indifferent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASCA
SPEECH.LINE: You speak to Casca, and to such a man
That is no fleering tell-tale. Hold, my hand:
Be factious for redress of all these griefs,
And I will set this foot of mine as far
As who goes farthest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASSIUS
SPEECH.LINE: There's a bargain made.
Now know you, Casca, I have moved already
Some certain of the noblest-minded Romans
To undergo with me an enterprise
Of honourable-dangerous consequence;
And I do know, by this, they stay for me
In Pompey's porch: for now, this fearful night,
There is no stir or walking in the streets;
And the complexion of the element
In favour's like the work we have in hand,
Most bloody, fiery, and most terrible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASCA
SPEECH.LINE: Stand close awhile, for here comes one in haste.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASSIUS
SPEECH.LINE: 'Tis Cinna; I do know him by his gait;
He is a friend.
Cinna, where haste you so?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CINNA
SPEECH.LINE: To find out you. Who's that? Metellus Cimber?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASSIUS
SPEECH.LINE: No, it is Casca; one incorporate
To our attempts. Am I not stay'd for, Cinna?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CINNA
SPEECH.LINE: I am glad on 't. What a fearful night is this!
There's two or three of us have seen strange sights.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASSIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Am I not stay'd for? tell me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CINNA
SPEECH.LINE: Yes, you are.
O Cassius, if you could
But win the noble Brutus to our party--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASSIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Be you content: good Cinna, take this paper,
And look you lay it in the praetor's chair,
Where Brutus may but find it; and throw this
In at his window; set this up with wax
Upon old Brutus' statue: all this done,
Repair to Pompey's porch, where you shall find us.
Is Decius Brutus and Trebonius there?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CINNA
SPEECH.LINE: All but Metellus Cimber; and he's gone
To seek you at your house. Well, I will hie,
And so bestow these papers as you bade me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASSIUS
SPEECH.LINE: That done, repair to Pompey's theatre.
Come, Casca, you and I will yet ere day
See Brutus at his house: three parts of him
Is ours already, and the man entire
Upon the next encounter yields him ours.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASCA
SPEECH.LINE: O, he sits high in all the people's hearts:
And that which would appear offence in us,
His countenance, like richest alchemy,
Will change to virtue and to worthiness.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASSIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Him and his worth and our great need of him
You have right well conceited. Let us go,
For it is after midnight; and ere day
We will awake him and be sure of him.

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE I. Rome. BRUTUS's orchard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: What, Lucius, ho!
I cannot, by the progress of the stars,
Give guess how near to day. Lucius, I say!
I would it were my fault to sleep so soundly.
When, Lucius, when? awake, I say! what, Lucius!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Call'd you, my lord?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Get me a taper in my study, Lucius:
When it is lighted, come and call me here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCIUS
SPEECH.LINE: I will, my lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: It must be by his death: and for my part,
I know no personal cause to spurn at him,
But for the general. He would be crown'd:
How that might change his nature, there's the question.
It is the bright day that brings forth the adder;
And that craves wary walking. Crown him?--that;--
And then, I grant, we put a sting in him,
That at his will he may do danger with.
The abuse of greatness is, when it disjoins
Remorse from power: and, to speak truth of Caesar,
I have not known when his affections sway'd
More than his reason. But 'tis a common proof,
That lowliness is young ambition's ladder,
Whereto the climber-upward turns his face;
But when he once attains the upmost round.
He then unto the ladder turns his back,
Looks in the clouds, scorning the base degrees
By which he did ascend. So Caesar may.
Then, lest he may, prevent. And, since the quarrel
Will bear no colour for the thing he is,
Fashion it thus; that what he is, augmented,
Would run to these and these extremities:
And therefore think him as a serpent's egg
Which, hatch'd, would, as his kind, grow mischievous,
And kill him in the shell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCIUS
SPEECH.LINE: The taper burneth in your closet, sir.
Searching the window for a flint, I found
This paper, thus seal'd up; and, I am sure,
It did not lie there when I went to bed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Get you to bed again; it is not day.
Is not to-morrow, boy, the ides of March?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCIUS
SPEECH.LINE: I know not, sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Look in the calendar, and bring me word.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCIUS
SPEECH.LINE: I will, sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: The exhalations whizzing in the air
Give so much light that I may read by them.
'Brutus, thou sleep'st: awake, and see thyself.
Shall Rome, &c. Speak, strike, redress!
Brutus, thou sleep'st: awake!'
Such instigations have been often dropp'd
Where I have took them up.
'Shall Rome, &c.' Thus must I piece it out:
Shall Rome stand under one man's awe? What, Rome?
My ancestors did from the streets of Rome
The Tarquin drive, when he was call'd a king.
'Speak, strike, redress!' Am I entreated
To speak and strike? O Rome, I make thee promise:
If the redress will follow, thou receivest
Thy full petition at the hand of Brutus!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, March is wasted fourteen days.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: 'Tis good. Go to the gate; somebody knocks.
Since Cassius first did whet me against Caesar,
I have not slept.
Between the acting of a dreadful thing
And the first motion, all the interim is
Like a phantasma, or a hideous dream:
The Genius and the mortal instruments
Are then in council; and the state of man,
Like to a little kingdom, suffers then
The nature of an insurrection.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, 'tis your brother Cassius at the door,
Who doth desire to see you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Is he alone?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCIUS
SPEECH.LINE: No, sir, there are moe with him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Do you know them?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCIUS
SPEECH.LINE: No, sir; their hats are pluck'd about their ears,
And half their faces buried in their cloaks,
That by no means I may discover them
By any mark of favour.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Let 'em enter.
They are the faction. O conspiracy,
Shamest thou to show thy dangerous brow by night,
When evils are most free? O, then by day
Where wilt thou find a cavern dark enough
To mask thy monstrous visage? Seek none, conspiracy;
Hide it in smiles and affability:
For if thou path, thy native semblance on,
Not Erebus itself were dim enough
To hide thee from prevention.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter the conspirators, CASSIUS, CASCA, DECIUS BRUTUS, CINNA, METELLUS CIMBER, and TREBONIUS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASSIUS
SPEECH.LINE: I think we are too bold upon your rest:
Good morrow, Brutus; do we trouble you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: I have been up this hour, awake all night.
Know I these men that come along with you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASSIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Yes, every man of them, and no man here
But honours you; and every one doth wish
You had but that opinion of yourself
Which every noble Roman bears of you.
This is Trebonius.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: He is welcome hither.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASSIUS
SPEECH.LINE: This, Decius Brutus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: He is welcome too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASSIUS
SPEECH.LINE: This, Casca; this, Cinna; and this, Metellus Cimber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: They are all welcome.
What watchful cares do interpose themselves
Betwixt your eyes and night?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASSIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Shall I entreat a word?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DECIUS BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Here lies the east: doth not the day break here?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASCA
SPEECH.LINE: No.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CINNA
SPEECH.LINE: O, pardon, sir, it doth; and yon gray lines
That fret the clouds are messengers of day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASCA
SPEECH.LINE: You shall confess that you are both deceived.
Here, as I point my sword, the sun arises,
Which is a great way growing on the south,
Weighing the youthful season of the year.
Some two months hence up higher toward the north
He first presents his fire; and the high east
Stands, as the Capitol, directly here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Give me your hands all over, one by one.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASSIUS
SPEECH.LINE: And let us swear our resolution.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: No, not an oath: if not the face of men,
The sufferance of our souls, the time's abuse,--
If these be motives weak, break off betimes,
And every man hence to his idle bed;
So let high-sighted tyranny range on,
Till each man drop by lottery. But if these,
As I am sure they do, bear fire enough
To kindle cowards and to steel with valour
The melting spirits of women, then, countrymen,
What need we any spur but our own cause,
To prick us to redress? what other bond
Than secret Romans, that have spoke the word,
And will not palter? and what other oath
Than honesty to honesty engaged,
That this shall be, or we will fall for it?
Swear priests and cowards and men cautelous,
Old feeble carrions and such suffering souls
That welcome wrongs; unto bad causes swear
Such creatures as men doubt; but do not stain
The even virtue of our enterprise,
Nor the insuppressive mettle of our spirits,
To think that or our cause or our performance
Did need an oath; when every drop of blood
That every Roman bears, and nobly bears,
Is guilty of a several bastardy,
If he do break the smallest particle
Of any promise that hath pass'd from him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASSIUS
SPEECH.LINE: But what of Cicero? shall we sound him?
I think he will stand very strong with us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASCA
SPEECH.LINE: Let us not leave him out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CINNA
SPEECH.LINE: No, by no means.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: METELLUS CIMBER
SPEECH.LINE: O, let us have him, for his silver hairs
Will purchase us a good opinion
And buy men's voices to commend our deeds:
It shall be said, his judgment ruled our hands;
Our youths and wildness shall no whit appear,
But all be buried in his gravity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: O, name him not: let us not break with him;
For he will never follow any thing
That other men begin.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASSIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Then leave him out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASCA
SPEECH.LINE: Indeed he is not fit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DECIUS BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Shall no man else be touch'd but only Caesar?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASSIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Decius, well urged: I think it is not meet,
Mark Antony, so well beloved of Caesar,
Should outlive Caesar: we shall find of him
A shrewd contriver; and, you know, his means,
If he improve them, may well stretch so far
As to annoy us all: which to prevent,
Let Antony and Caesar fall together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Our course will seem too bloody, Caius Cassius,
To cut the head off and then hack the limbs,
Like wrath in death and envy afterwards;
For Antony is but a limb of Caesar:
Let us be sacrificers, but not butchers, Caius.
We all stand up against the spirit of Caesar;
And in the spirit of men there is no blood:
O, that we then could come by Caesar's spirit,
And not dismember Caesar! But, alas,
Caesar must bleed for it! And, gentle friends,
Let's kill him boldly, but not wrathfully;
Let's carve him as a dish fit for the gods,
Not hew him as a carcass fit for hounds:
And let our hearts, as subtle masters do,
Stir up their servants to an act of rage,
And after seem to chide 'em. This shall make
Our purpose necessary and not envious:
Which so appearing to the common eyes,
We shall be call'd purgers, not murderers.
And for Mark Antony, think not of him;
For he can do no more than Caesar's arm
When Caesar's head is off.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASSIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Yet I fear him;
For in the ingrafted love he bears to Caesar--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Alas, good Cassius, do not think of him:
If he love Caesar, all that he can do
Is to himself, take thought and die for Caesar:
And that were much he should; for he is given
To sports, to wildness and much company.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TREBONIUS
SPEECH.LINE: There is no fear in him; let him not die;
For he will live, and laugh at this hereafter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Peace! count the clock.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASSIUS
SPEECH.LINE: The clock hath stricken three.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TREBONIUS
SPEECH.LINE: 'Tis time to part.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASSIUS
SPEECH.LINE: But it is doubtful yet,
Whether Caesar will come forth to-day, or no;
For he is superstitious grown of late,
Quite from the main opinion he held once
Of fantasy, of dreams and ceremonies:
It may be, these apparent prodigies,
The unaccustom'd terror of this night,
And the persuasion of his augurers,
May hold him from the Capitol to-day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DECIUS BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Never fear that: if he be so resolved,
I can o'ersway him; for he loves to hear
That unicorns may be betray'd with trees,
And bears with glasses, elephants with holes,
Lions with toils and men with flatterers;
But when I tell him he hates flatterers,
He says he does, being then most flattered.
Let me work;
For I can give his humour the true bent,
And I will bring him to the Capitol.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASSIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, we will all of us be there to fetch him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: By the eighth hour: is that the uttermost?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CINNA
SPEECH.LINE: Be that the uttermost, and fail not then.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: METELLUS CIMBER
SPEECH.LINE: Caius Ligarius doth bear Caesar hard,
Who rated him for speaking well of Pompey:
I wonder none of you have thought of him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Now, good Metellus, go along by him:
He loves me well, and I have given him reasons;
Send him but hither, and I'll fashion him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASSIUS
SPEECH.LINE: The morning comes upon 's: we'll leave you, Brutus.
And, friends, disperse yourselves; but all remember
What you have said, and show yourselves true Romans.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Good gentlemen, look fresh and merrily;
Let not our looks put on our purposes,
But bear it as our Roman actors do,
With untired spirits and formal constancy:
And so good morrow to you every one.
Boy! Lucius! Fast asleep? It is no matter;
Enjoy the honey-heavy dew of slumber:
Thou hast no figures nor no fantasies,
Which busy care draws in the brains of men;
Therefore thou sleep'st so sound.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PORTIA
SPEECH.LINE: Brutus, my lord!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Portia, what mean you? wherefore rise you now?
It is not for your health thus to commit
Your weak condition to the raw cold morning.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PORTIA
SPEECH.LINE: Nor for yours neither. You've ungently, Brutus,
Stole from my bed: and yesternight, at supper,
You suddenly arose, and walk'd about,
Musing and sighing, with your arms across,
And when I ask'd you what the matter was,
You stared upon me with ungentle looks;
I urged you further; then you scratch'd your head,
And too impatiently stamp'd with your foot;
Yet I insisted, yet you answer'd not,
But, with an angry wafture of your hand,
Gave sign for me to leave you: so I did;
Fearing to strengthen that impatience
Which seem'd too much enkindled, and withal
Hoping it was but an effect of humour,
Which sometime hath his hour with every man.
It will not let you eat, nor talk, nor sleep,
And could it work so much upon your shape
As it hath much prevail'd on your condition,
I should not know you, Brutus. Dear my lord,
Make me acquainted with your cause of grief.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: I am not well in health, and that is all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PORTIA
SPEECH.LINE: Brutus is wise, and, were he not in health,
He would embrace the means to come by it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Why, so I do. Good Portia, go to bed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PORTIA
SPEECH.LINE: Is Brutus sick? and is it physical
To walk unbraced and suck up the humours
Of the dank morning? What, is Brutus sick,
And will he steal out of his wholesome bed,
To dare the vile contagion of the night
And tempt the rheumy and unpurged air
To add unto his sickness? No, my Brutus;
You have some sick offence within your mind,
Which, by the right and virtue of my place,
I ought to know of: and, upon my knees,
I charm you, by my once-commended beauty,
By all your vows of love and that great vow
Which did incorporate and make us one,
That you unfold to me, yourself, your half,
Why you are heavy, and what men to-night
Have had to resort to you: for here have been
Some six or seven, who did hide their faces
Even from darkness.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Kneel not, gentle Portia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PORTIA
SPEECH.LINE: I should not need, if you were gentle Brutus.
Within the bond of marriage, tell me, Brutus,
Is it excepted I should know no secrets
That appertain to you? Am I yourself
But, as it were, in sort or limitation,
To keep with you at meals, comfort your bed,
And talk to you sometimes? Dwell I but in the suburbs
Of your good pleasure? If it be no more,
Portia is Brutus' harlot, not his wife.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: You are my true and honourable wife,
As dear to me as are the ruddy drops
That visit my sad heart

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PORTIA
SPEECH.LINE: If this were true, then should I know this secret.
I grant I am a woman; but withal
A woman that Lord Brutus took to wife:
I grant I am a woman; but withal
A woman well-reputed, Cato's daughter.
Think you I am no stronger than my sex,
Being so father'd and so husbanded?
Tell me your counsels, I will not disclose 'em:
I have made strong proof of my constancy,
Giving myself a voluntary wound
Here, in the thigh: can I bear that with patience.
And not my husband's secrets?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: O ye gods,
Render me worthy of this noble wife!
Hark, hark! one knocks: Portia, go in awhile;
And by and by thy bosom shall partake
The secrets of my heart.
All my engagements I will construe to thee,
All the charactery of my sad brows:
Leave me with haste.
Lucius, who's that knocks?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCIUS
SPEECH.LINE: He is a sick man that would speak with you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Caius Ligarius, that Metellus spake of.
Boy, stand aside. Caius Ligarius! how?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LIGARIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Vouchsafe good morrow from a feeble tongue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: O, what a time have you chose out, brave Caius,
To wear a kerchief! Would you were not sick!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LIGARIUS
SPEECH.LINE: I am not sick, if Brutus have in hand
Any exploit worthy the name of honour.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Such an exploit have I in hand, Ligarius,
Had you a healthful ear to hear of it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LIGARIUS
SPEECH.LINE: By all the gods that Romans bow before,
I here discard my sickness! Soul of Rome!
Brave son, derived from honourable loins!
Thou, like an exorcist, hast conjured up
My mortified spirit. Now bid me run,
And I will strive with things impossible;
Yea, get the better of them. What's to do?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: A piece of work that will make sick men whole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LIGARIUS
SPEECH.LINE: But are not some whole that we must make sick?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: That must we also. What it is, my Caius,
I shall unfold to thee, as we are going
To whom it must be done.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LIGARIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Set on your foot,
And with a heart new-fired I follow you,
To do I know not what: but it sufficeth
That Brutus leads me on.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Follow me, then.

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE II. CAESAR's house.
SCENE.STAGEDIR: Thunder and lightning. Enter CAESAR, in his night-gown

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CAESAR
SPEECH.LINE: Nor heaven nor earth have been at peace to-night:
Thrice hath Calpurnia in her sleep cried out,
'Help, ho! they murder Caesar!' Who's within?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Servant
SPEECH.LINE: My lord?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CAESAR
SPEECH.LINE: Go bid the priests do present sacrifice
And bring me their opinions of success.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Servant
SPEECH.LINE: I will, my lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CALPURNIA
SPEECH.LINE: What mean you, Caesar? think you to walk forth?
You shall not stir out of your house to-day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CAESAR
SPEECH.LINE: Caesar shall forth: the things that threaten'd me
Ne'er look'd but on my back; when they shall see
The face of Caesar, they are vanished.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CALPURNIA
SPEECH.LINE: Caesar, I never stood on ceremonies,
Yet now they fright me. There is one within,
Besides the things that we have heard and seen,
Recounts most horrid sights seen by the watch.
A lioness hath whelped in the streets;
And graves have yawn'd, and yielded up their dead;
Fierce fiery warriors fought upon the clouds,
In ranks and squadrons and right form of war,
Which drizzled blood upon the Capitol;
The noise of battle hurtled in the air,
Horses did neigh, and dying men did groan,
And ghosts did shriek and squeal about the streets.
O Caesar! these things are beyond all use,
And I do fear them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CAESAR
SPEECH.LINE: What can be avoided
Whose end is purposed by the mighty gods?
Yet Caesar shall go forth; for these predictions
Are to the world in general as to Caesar.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CALPURNIA
SPEECH.LINE: When beggars die, there are no comets seen;
The heavens themselves blaze forth the death of princes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CAESAR
SPEECH.LINE: Cowards die many times before their deaths;
The valiant never taste of death but once.
Of all the wonders that I yet have heard.
It seems to me most strange that men should fear;
Seeing that death, a necessary end,
Will come when it will come.
What say the augurers?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Servant
SPEECH.LINE: They would not have you to stir forth to-day.
Plucking the entrails of an offering forth,
They could not find a heart within the beast.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CAESAR
SPEECH.LINE: The gods do this in shame of cowardice:
Caesar should be a beast without a heart,
If he should stay at home to-day for fear.
No, Caesar shall not: danger knows full well
That Caesar is more dangerous than he:
We are two lions litter'd in one day,
And I the elder and more terrible:
And Caesar shall go forth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CALPURNIA
SPEECH.LINE: Alas, my lord,
Your wisdom is consumed in confidence.
Do not go forth to-day: call it my fear
That keeps you in the house, and not your own.
We'll send Mark Antony to the senate-house:
And he shall say you are not well to-day:
Let me, upon my knee, prevail in this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CAESAR
SPEECH.LINE: Mark Antony shall say I am not well,
And, for thy humour, I will stay at home.
Here's Decius Brutus, he shall tell them so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DECIUS BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Caesar, all hail! good morrow, worthy Caesar:
I come to fetch you to the senate-house.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CAESAR
SPEECH.LINE: And you are come in very happy time,
To bear my greeting to the senators
And tell them that I will not come to-day:
Cannot, is false, and that I dare not, falser:
I will not come to-day: tell them so, Decius.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CALPURNIA
SPEECH.LINE: Say he is sick.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CAESAR
SPEECH.LINE: Shall Caesar send a lie?
Have I in conquest stretch'd mine arm so far,
To be afraid to tell graybeards the truth?
Decius, go tell them Caesar will not come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DECIUS BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Most mighty Caesar, let me know some cause,
Lest I be laugh'd at when I tell them so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CAESAR
SPEECH.LINE: The cause is in my will: I will not come;
That is enough to satisfy the senate.
But for your private satisfaction,
Because I love you, I will let you know:
Calpurnia here, my wife, stays me at home:
She dreamt to-night she saw my statua,
Which, like a fountain with an hundred spouts,
Did run pure blood: and many lusty Romans
Came smiling, and did bathe their hands in it:
And these does she apply for warnings, and portents,
And evils imminent; and on her knee
Hath begg'd that I will stay at home to-day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DECIUS BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: This dream is all amiss interpreted;
It was a vision fair and fortunate:
Your statue spouting blood in many pipes,
In which so many smiling Romans bathed,
Signifies that from you great Rome shall suck
Reviving blood, and that great men shall press
For tinctures, stains, relics and cognizance.
This by Calpurnia's dream is signified.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CAESAR
SPEECH.LINE: And this way have you well expounded it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DECIUS BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: I have, when you have heard what I can say:
And know it now: the senate have concluded
To give this day a crown to mighty Caesar.
If you shall send them word you will not come,
Their minds may change. Besides, it were a mock
Apt to be render'd, for some one to say
'Break up the senate till another time,
When Caesar's wife shall meet with better dreams.'
If Caesar hide himself, shall they not whisper
'Lo, Caesar is afraid'?
Pardon me, Caesar; for my dear dear love
To our proceeding bids me tell you this;
And reason to my love is liable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CAESAR
SPEECH.LINE: How foolish do your fears seem now, Calpurnia!
I am ashamed I did yield to them.
Give me my robe, for I will go.
SPEECH.STAGEDIR: Enter PUBLIUS, BRUTUS, LIGARIUS, METELLUS, CASCA, TREBONIUS, and CINNA
SPEECH.LINE: And look where Publius is come to fetch me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PUBLIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Good morrow, Caesar.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CAESAR
SPEECH.LINE: Welcome, Publius.
What, Brutus, are you stirr'd so early too?
Good morrow, Casca. Caius Ligarius,
Caesar was ne'er so much your enemy
As that same ague which hath made you lean.
What is 't o'clock?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Caesar, 'tis strucken eight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CAESAR
SPEECH.LINE: I thank you for your pains and courtesy.
See! Antony, that revels long o' nights,
Is notwithstanding up. Good morrow, Antony.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTONY
SPEECH.LINE: So to most noble Caesar.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CAESAR
SPEECH.LINE: Bid them prepare within:
I am to blame to be thus waited for.
Now, Cinna: now, Metellus: what, Trebonius!
I have an hour's talk in store for you;
Remember that you call on me to-day:
Be near me, that I may remember you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TREBONIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Caesar, I will:
and so near will I be,
That your best friends shall wish I had been further.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CAESAR
SPEECH.LINE: Good friends, go in, and taste some wine with me;
And we, like friends, will straightway go together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Aside That every like is not the same, O Caesar,
The heart of Brutus yearns to think upon!

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE III. A street near the Capitol.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ARTEMIDORUS
SPEECH.LINE: 'Caesar, beware of Brutus; take heed of Cassius;
come not near Casca; have an eye to Cinna, trust not
Trebonius: mark well Metellus Cimber: Decius Brutus
loves thee not: thou hast wronged Caius Ligarius.
There is but one mind in all these men, and it is
bent against Caesar. If thou beest not immortal,
look about you: security gives way to conspiracy.
The mighty gods defend thee! Thy lover,
'ARTEMIDORUS.'
Here will I stand till Caesar pass along,
And as a suitor will I give him this.
My heart laments that virtue cannot live
Out of the teeth of emulation.
If thou read this, O Caesar, thou mayst live;
If not, the Fates with traitors do contrive.

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE IV. Another part of the same street, before the house of BRUTUS.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PORTIA
SPEECH.LINE: I prithee, boy, run to the senate-house;
Stay not to answer me, but get thee gone:
Why dost thou stay?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCIUS
SPEECH.LINE: To know my errand, madam.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PORTIA
SPEECH.LINE: I would have had thee there, and here again,
Ere I can tell thee what thou shouldst do there.
O constancy, be strong upon my side,
Set a huge mountain 'tween my heart and tongue!
I have a man's mind, but a woman's might.
How hard it is for women to keep counsel!
Art thou here yet?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Madam, what should I do?
Run to the Capitol, and nothing else?
And so return to you, and nothing else?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PORTIA
SPEECH.LINE: Yes, bring me word, boy, if thy lord look well,
For he went sickly forth: and take good note
What Caesar doth, what suitors press to him.
Hark, boy! what noise is that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCIUS
SPEECH.LINE: I hear none, madam.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PORTIA
SPEECH.LINE: Prithee, listen well;
I heard a bustling rumour, like a fray,
And the wind brings it from the Capitol.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LUCIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Sooth, madam, I hear nothing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PORTIA
SPEECH.LINE: Come hither, fellow: which way hast thou been?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Soothsayer
SPEECH.LINE: At mine own house, good lady.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PORTIA
SPEECH.LINE: What is't o'clock?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Soothsayer
SPEECH.LINE: About the ninth hour, lady.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PORTIA
SPEECH.LINE: Is Caesar yet gone to the Capitol?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Soothsayer
SPEECH.LINE: Madam, not yet: I go to take my stand,
To see him pass on to the Capitol.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PORTIA
SPEECH.LINE: Thou hast some suit to Caesar, hast thou not?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Soothsayer
SPEECH.LINE: That I have, lady: if it will please Caesar
To be so good to Caesar as to hear me,
I shall beseech him to befriend himself.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PORTIA
SPEECH.LINE: Why, know'st thou any harm's intended towards him?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Soothsayer
SPEECH.LINE: None that I know will be, much that I fear may chance.
Good morrow to you. Here the street is narrow:
The throng that follows Caesar at the heels,
Of senators, of praetors, common suitors,
Will crowd a feeble man almost to death:
I'll get me to a place more void, and there
Speak to great Caesar as he comes along.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PORTIA
SPEECH.LINE: I must go in. Ay me, how weak a thing
The heart of woman is! O Brutus,
The heavens speed thee in thine enterprise!
Sure, the boy heard me: Brutus hath a suit
That Caesar will not grant. O, I grow faint.
Run, Lucius, and commend me to my lord;
Say I am merry: come to me again,
And bring me word what he doth say to thee.

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE I. Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
SCENE.STAGEDIR: A crowd of people; among them ARTEMIDORUS and the Soothsayer. Flourish. Enter CAESAR, BRUTUS, CASSIUS, CASCA, DECIUS BRUTUS, METELLUS CIMBER, TREBONIUS, CINNA, ANTONY, LEPIDUS, POPILIUS, PUBLIUS, and others

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CAESAR
SPEECH.LINE: To the Soothsayer The ides of March are come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Soothsayer
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, Caesar; but not gone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ARTEMIDORUS
SPEECH.LINE: Hail, Caesar! read this schedule.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DECIUS BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Trebonius doth desire you to o'erread,
At your best leisure, this his humble suit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ARTEMIDORUS
SPEECH.LINE: O Caesar, read mine first; for mine's a suit
That touches Caesar nearer: read it, great Caesar.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CAESAR
SPEECH.LINE: What touches us ourself shall be last served.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ARTEMIDORUS
SPEECH.LINE: Delay not, Caesar; read it instantly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CAESAR
SPEECH.LINE: What, is the fellow mad?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PUBLIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Sirrah, give place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASSIUS
SPEECH.LINE: What, urge you your petitions in the street?
Come to the Capitol.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: CAESAR goes up to the Senate-House, the rest following

SPEECH.SPEAKER: POPILIUS
SPEECH.LINE: I wish your enterprise to-day may thrive.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASSIUS
SPEECH.LINE: What enterprise, Popilius?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: POPILIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Fare you well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: What said Popilius Lena?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASSIUS
SPEECH.LINE: He wish'd to-day our enterprise might thrive.
I fear our purpose is discovered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Look, how he makes to Caesar; mark him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASSIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Casca, be sudden, for we fear prevention.
Brutus, what shall be done? If this be known,
Cassius or Caesar never shall turn back,
For I will slay myself.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Cassius, be constant:
Popilius Lena speaks not of our purposes;
For, look, he smiles, and Caesar doth not change.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASSIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Trebonius knows his time; for, look you, Brutus.
He draws Mark Antony out of the way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DECIUS BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Where is Metellus Cimber? Let him go,
And presently prefer his suit to Caesar.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: He is address'd: press near and second him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CINNA
SPEECH.LINE: Casca, you are the first that rears your hand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CAESAR
SPEECH.LINE: Are we all ready? What is now amiss
That Caesar and his senate must redress?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: METELLUS CIMBER
SPEECH.LINE: Most high, most mighty, and most puissant Caesar,
Metellus Cimber throws before thy seat
An humble heart,--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CAESAR
SPEECH.LINE: I must prevent thee, Cimber.
These couchings and these lowly courtesies
Might fire the blood of ordinary men,
And turn pre-ordinance and first decree
Into the law of children. Be not fond,
To think that Caesar bears such rebel blood
That will be thaw'd from the true quality
With that which melteth fools; I mean, sweet words,
Low-crooked court'sies and base spaniel-fawning.
Thy brother by decree is banished:
If thou dost bend and pray and fawn for him,
I spurn thee like a cur out of my way.
Know, Caesar doth not wrong, nor without cause
Will he be satisfied.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: METELLUS CIMBER
SPEECH.LINE: Is there no voice more worthy than my own
To sound more sweetly in great Caesar's ear
For the repealing of my banish'd brother?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: I kiss thy hand, but not in flattery, Caesar;
Desiring thee that Publius Cimber may
Have an immediate freedom of repeal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CAESAR
SPEECH.LINE: What, Brutus!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASSIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Pardon, Caesar; Caesar, pardon:
As low as to thy foot doth Cassius fall,
To beg enfranchisement for Publius Cimber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASSIUS
SPEECH.LINE: I could be well moved, if I were as you:
If I could pray to move, prayers would move me:
But I am constant as the northern star,
Of whose true-fix'd and resting quality
There is no fellow in the firmament.
The skies are painted with unnumber'd sparks,
They are all fire and every one doth shine,
But there's but one in all doth hold his place:
So in the world; 'tis furnish'd well with men,
And men are flesh and blood, and apprehensive;
Yet in the number I do know but one
That unassailable holds on his rank,
Unshaked of motion: and that I am he,
Let me a little show it, even in this;
That I was constant Cimber should be banish'd,
And constant do remain to keep him so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CINNA
SPEECH.LINE: O Caesar,--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CAESAR
SPEECH.LINE: Hence! wilt thou lift up Olympus?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DECIUS BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Great Caesar,--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CAESAR
SPEECH.LINE: Doth not Brutus bootless kneel?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASCA
SPEECH.LINE: Speak, hands for me!

SCENE.STAGEDIR: CASCA first, then the other Conspirators and BRUTUS stab CAESAR

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CAESAR
SPEECH.LINE: Et tu, Brute! Then fall, Caesar.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CINNA
SPEECH.LINE: Liberty! Freedom! Tyranny is dead!
Run hence, proclaim, cry it about the streets.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASSIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Some to the common pulpits, and cry out
'Liberty, freedom, and enfranchisement!'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: People and senators, be not affrighted;
Fly not; stand stiff: ambition's debt is paid.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASCA
SPEECH.LINE: Go to the pulpit, Brutus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DECIUS BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: And Cassius too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Where's Publius?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CINNA
SPEECH.LINE: Here, quite confounded with this mutiny.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: METELLUS CIMBER
SPEECH.LINE: Stand fast together, lest some friend of Caesar's
Should chance--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Talk not of standing. Publius, good cheer;
There is no harm intended to your person,
Nor to no Roman else: so tell them, Publius.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASSIUS
SPEECH.LINE: And leave us, Publius; lest that the people,
Rushing on us, should do your age some mischief.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Do so: and let no man abide this deed,
But we the doers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASSIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Where is Antony?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TREBONIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Fled to his house amazed:
Men, wives and children stare, cry out and run
As it were doomsday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Fates, we will know your pleasures:
That we shall die, we know; 'tis but the time
And drawing days out, that men stand upon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASSIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Why, he that cuts off twenty years of life
Cuts off so many years of fearing death.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Grant that, and then is death a benefit:
So are we Caesar's friends, that have abridged
His time of fearing death. Stoop, Romans, stoop,
And let us bathe our hands in Caesar's blood
Up to the elbows, and besmear our swords:
Then walk we forth, even to the market-place,
And, waving our red weapons o'er our heads,
Let's all cry 'Peace, freedom and liberty!'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASSIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Stoop, then, and wash. How many ages hence
Shall this our lofty scene be acted over
In states unborn and accents yet unknown!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: How many times shall Caesar bleed in sport,
That now on Pompey's basis lies along
No worthier than the dust!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASSIUS
SPEECH.LINE: So oft as that shall be,
So often shall the knot of us be call'd
The men that gave their country liberty.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DECIUS BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: What, shall we forth?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASSIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, every man away:
Brutus shall lead; and we will grace his heels
With the most boldest and best hearts of Rome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Soft! who comes here? A friend of Antony's.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Servant
SPEECH.LINE: Thus, Brutus, did my master bid me kneel:
Thus did Mark Antony bid me fall down;
And, being prostrate, thus he bade me say:
Brutus is noble, wise, valiant, and honest;
Caesar was mighty, bold, royal, and loving:
Say I love Brutus, and I honour him;
Say I fear'd Caesar, honour'd him and loved him.
If Brutus will vouchsafe that Antony
May safely come to him, and be resolved
How Caesar hath deserved to lie in death,
Mark Antony shall not love Caesar dead
So well as Brutus living; but will follow
The fortunes and affairs of noble Brutus
Thorough the hazards of this untrod state
With all true faith. So says my master Antony.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Thy master is a wise and valiant Roman;
I never thought him worse.
Tell him, so please him come unto this place,
He shall be satisfied; and, by my honour,
Depart untouch'd.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Servant
SPEECH.LINE: I'll fetch him presently.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: I know that we shall have him well to friend.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASSIUS
SPEECH.LINE: I wish we may: but yet have I a mind
That fears him much; and my misgiving still
Falls shrewdly to the purpose.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: But here comes Antony.
Welcome, Mark Antony.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTONY
SPEECH.LINE: O mighty Caesar! dost thou lie so low?
Are all thy conquests, glories, triumphs, spoils,
Shrunk to this little measure? Fare thee well.
I know not, gentlemen, what you intend,
Who else must be let blood, who else is rank:
If I myself, there is no hour so fit
As Caesar's death hour, nor no instrument
Of half that worth as those your swords, made rich
With the most noble blood of all this world.
I do beseech ye, if you bear me hard,
Now, whilst your purpled hands do reek and smoke,
Fulfil your pleasure. Live a thousand years,
I shall not find myself so apt to die:
No place will please me so, no mean of death,
As here by Caesar, and by you cut off,
The choice and master spirits of this age.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: O Antony, beg not your death of us.
Though now we must appear bloody and cruel,
As, by our hands and this our present act,
You see we do, yet see you but our hands
And this the bleeding business they have done:
Our hearts you see not; they are pitiful;
And pity to the general wrong of Rome--
As fire drives out fire, so pity pity--
Hath done this deed on Caesar. For your part,
To you our swords have leaden points, Mark Antony:
Our arms, in strength of malice, and our hearts
Of brothers' temper, do receive you in
With all kind love, good thoughts, and reverence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASSIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Your voice shall be as strong as any man's
In the disposing of new dignities.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Only be patient till we have appeased
The multitude, beside themselves with fear,
And then we will deliver you the cause,
Why I, that did love Caesar when I struck him,
Have thus proceeded.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTONY
SPEECH.LINE: I doubt not of your wisdom.
Let each man render me his bloody hand:
First, Marcus Brutus, will I shake with you;
Next, Caius Cassius, do I take your hand;
Now, Decius Brutus, yours: now yours, Metellus;
Yours, Cinna; and, my valiant Casca, yours;
Though last, not last in love, yours, good Trebonius.
Gentlemen all,--alas, what shall I say?
My credit now stands on such slippery ground,
That one of two bad ways you must conceit me,
Either a coward or a flatterer.
That I did love thee, Caesar, O, 'tis true:
If then thy spirit look upon us now,
Shall it not grieve thee dearer than thy death,
To see thy thy Anthony making his peace,
Shaking the bloody fingers of thy foes,
Most noble! in the presence of thy corse?
Had I as many eyes as thou hast wounds,
Weeping as fast as they stream forth thy blood,
It would become me better than to close
In terms of friendship with thine enemies.
Pardon me, Julius! Here wast thou bay'd, brave hart;
Here didst thou fall; and here thy hunters stand,
Sign'd in thy spoil, and crimson'd in thy lethe.
O world, thou wast the forest to this hart;
And this, indeed, O world, the heart of thee.
How like a deer, strucken by many princes,
Dost thou here lie!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASSIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Mark Antony,--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTONY
SPEECH.LINE: Pardon me, Caius Cassius:
The enemies of Caesar shall say this;
Then, in a friend, it is cold modesty.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASSIUS
SPEECH.LINE: I blame you not for praising Caesar so;
But what compact mean you to have with us?
Will you be prick'd in number of our friends;
Or shall we on, and not depend on you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTONY
SPEECH.LINE: Therefore I took your hands, but was, indeed,
Sway'd from the point, by looking down on Caesar.
Friends am I with you all and love you all,
Upon this hope, that you shall give me reasons
Why and wherein Caesar was dangerous.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Or else were this a savage spectacle:
Our reasons are so full of good regard
That were you, Antony, the son of Caesar,
You should be satisfied.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTONY
SPEECH.LINE: That's all I seek:
And am moreover suitor that I may
Produce his body to the market-place;
And in the pulpit, as becomes a friend,
Speak in the order of his funeral.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: You shall, Mark Antony.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASSIUS
SPEECH.LINE: Brutus, a word with you.
You know not what you do: do not consent
That Antony speak in his funeral:
Know you how much the people may be moved
By that which he will utter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: By your pardon;
I will myself into the pulpit first,
And show the reason of our Caesar's death:
What Antony shall speak, I will protest
He speaks by leave and by permission,
And that we are contented Caesar shall
Have all true rites and lawful ceremonies.
It shall advantage more than do us wrong.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CASSIUS
SPEECH.LINE: I know not what may fall; I like it not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Mark Antony, here, take you Caesar's body.
You shall not in your funeral speech blame us,
But speak all good you can devise of Caesar,
And say you do't by our permission;
Else shall you not have any hand at all
About his funeral: and you shall speak
In the same pulpit whereto I am going,
After my speech is ended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTONY
SPEECH.LINE: Be it so.
I do desire no more.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Prepare the body then, and follow us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTONY
SPEECH.LINE: O, pardon me, thou bleeding piece of earth,
That I am meek and gentle with these butchers!
Thou art the ruins of the noblest man
That ever lived in the tide of times.
Woe to the hand that shed this costly blood!
Over thy wounds now do I prophesy,--
Which, like dumb mouths, do ope their ruby lips,
To beg the voice and utterance of my tongue--
A curse shall light upon the limbs of men;
Domestic fury and fierce civil strife
Shall cumber all the parts of Italy;
Blood and destruction shall be so in use
And dreadful objects so familiar
That mothers shall but smile when they behold
Their infants quarter'd with the hands of war;
All pity choked with custom of fell deeds:
And Caesar's spirit, ranging for revenge,
With Ate by his side come hot from hell,
Shall in these confines with a monarch's voice
Cry 'Havoc,' and let slip the dogs of war;
That this foul deed shall smell above the earth
With carrion men, groaning for burial.
You serve Octavius Caesar, do you not?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Servant
SPEECH.LINE: I do, Mark Antony.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTONY
SPEECH.LINE: Caesar did write for him to come to Rome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Servant
SPEECH.LINE: He did receive his letters, and is coming;
And bid me say to you by word of mouth--
O Caesar!--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTONY
SPEECH.LINE: Thy heart is big, get thee apart and weep.
Passion, I see, is catching; for mine eyes,
Seeing those beads of sorrow stand in thine,
Began to water. Is thy master coming?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Servant
SPEECH.LINE: He lies to-night within seven leagues of Rome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTONY
SPEECH.LINE: Post back with speed, and tell him what hath chanced:
Here is a mourning Rome, a dangerous Rome,
No Rome of safety for Octavius yet;
Hie hence, and tell him so. Yet, stay awhile;
Thou shalt not back till I have borne this corse
Into the market-place: there shall I try
In my oration, how the people take
The cruel issue of these bloody men;
According to the which, thou shalt discourse
To young Octavius of the state of things.
Lend me your hand.

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE II. The Forum.
SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter BRUTUS and CASSIUS, and a throng of Citizens

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Citizens
SPEECH.LINE: We will be satisfied; let us be satisfied.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Then follow me, and give me audience, friends.
Cassius, go you into the other street,
And part the numbers.
Those that will hear me speak, let 'em stay here;
Those that will follow Cassius, go with him;
And public reasons shall be rendered
Of Caesar's death.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: I will hear Brutus speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Second Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: I will hear Cassius; and compare their reasons,
When severally we hear them rendered.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Exit CASSIUS, with some of the Citizens. BRUTUS goes into the pulpit

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Third Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: The noble Brutus is ascended: silence!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Be patient till the last.
Romans, countrymen, and lovers! hear me for my
cause, and be silent, that you may hear: believe me
for mine honour, and have respect to mine honour, that
you may believe: censure me in your wisdom, and
awake your senses, that you may the better judge.
If there be any in this assembly, any dear friend of
Caesar's, to him I say, that Brutus' love to Caesar
was no less than his. If then that friend demand
why Brutus rose against Caesar, this is my answer:
--Not that I loved Caesar less, but that I loved
Rome more. Had you rather Caesar were living and
die all slaves, than that Caesar were dead, to live
all free men? As Caesar loved me, I weep for him;
as he was fortunate, I rejoice at it; as he was
valiant, I honour him: but, as he was ambitious, I
slew him. There is tears for his love; joy for his
fortune; honour for his valour; and death for his
ambition. Who is here so base that would be a
bondman? If any, speak; for him have I offended.
Who is here so rude that would not be a Roman? If
any, speak; for him have I offended. Who is here so
vile that will not love his country? If any, speak;
for him have I offended. I pause for a reply.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: All
SPEECH.LINE: None, Brutus, none.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Then none have I offended. I have done no more to
Caesar than you shall do to Brutus. The question of
his death is enrolled in the Capitol; his glory not
extenuated, wherein he was worthy, nor his offences
enforced, for which he suffered death.
SPEECH.STAGEDIR: Enter ANTONY and others, with CAESAR's body
SPEECH.LINE: Here comes his body, mourned by Mark Antony: who,
though he had no hand in his death, shall receive
the benefit of his dying, a place in the
commonwealth; as which of you shall not? With this
I depart,--that, as I slew my best lover for the
good of Rome, I have the same dagger for myself,
when it shall please my country to need my death.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: All
SPEECH.LINE: Live, Brutus! live, live!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: Bring him with triumph home unto his house.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Second Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: Give him a statue with his ancestors.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Third Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: Let him be Caesar.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fourth Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: Caesar's better parts
Shall be crown'd in Brutus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: We'll bring him to his house
With shouts and clamours.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: My countrymen,--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Second Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: Peace, silence! Brutus speaks.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: Peace, ho!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BRUTUS
SPEECH.LINE: Good countrymen, let me depart alone,
And, for my sake, stay here with Antony:
Do grace to Caesar's corpse, and grace his speech
Tending to Caesar's glories; which Mark Antony,
By our permission, is allow'd to make.
I do entreat you, not a man depart,
Save I alone, till Antony have spoke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: Stay, ho! and let us hear Mark Antony.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Third Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: Let him go up into the public chair;
We'll hear him. Noble Antony, go up.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTONY
SPEECH.LINE: For Brutus' sake, I am beholding to you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fourth Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: What does he say of Brutus?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Third Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: He says, for Brutus' sake,
He finds himself beholding to us all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fourth Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: 'Twere best he speak no harm of Brutus here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: This Caesar was a tyrant.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Third Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, that's certain:
We are blest that Rome is rid of him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Second Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: Peace! let us hear what Antony can say.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTONY
SPEECH.LINE: You gentle Romans,--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Citizens
SPEECH.LINE: Peace, ho! let us hear him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTONY
SPEECH.LINE: Friends, Romans, countrymen, lend me your ears;
I come to bury Caesar, not to praise him.
The evil that men do lives after them;
The good is oft interred with their bones;
So let it be with Caesar. The noble Brutus
Hath told you Caesar was ambitious:
If it were so, it was a grievous fault,
And grievously hath Caesar answer'd it.
Here, under leave of Brutus and the rest--
For Brutus is an honourable man;
So are they all, all honourable men--
Come I to speak in Caesar's funeral.
He was my friend, faithful and just to me:
But Brutus says he was ambitious;
And Brutus is an honourable man.
He hath brought many captives home to Rome
Whose ransoms did the general coffers fill:
Did this in Caesar seem ambitious?
When that the poor have cried, Caesar hath wept:
Ambition should be made of sterner stuff:
Yet Brutus says he was ambitious;
And Brutus is an honourable man.
You all did see that on the Lupercal
I thrice presented him a kingly crown,
Which he did thrice refuse: was this ambition?
Yet Brutus says he was ambitious;
And, sure, he is an honourable man.
I speak not to disprove what Brutus spoke,
But here I am to speak what I do know.
You all did love him once, not without cause:
What cause withholds you then, to mourn for him?
O judgment! thou art fled to brutish beasts,
And men have lost their reason. Bear with me;
My heart is in the coffin there with Caesar,
And I must pause till it come back to me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: Methinks there is much reason in his sayings.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Second Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: If thou consider rightly of the matter,
Caesar has had great wrong.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Third Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: Has he, masters?
I fear there will a worse come in his place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fourth Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: Mark'd ye his words? He would not take the crown;
Therefore 'tis certain he was not ambitious.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: If it be found so, some will dear abide it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Second Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: Poor soul! his eyes are red as fire with weeping.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Third Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: There's not a nobler man in Rome than Antony.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fourth Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: Now mark him, he begins again to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ANTONY
SPEECH.LINE: But yesterday the word of Caesar might
